Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Comparative Phylogeographic Approach to Predicting Cryptic Diversity - The Inland Temperate Rainforest as a Model System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biologists have been conducting surveys aimed at discovering and describing species for centuries. However, it is not known how many species are on the Earth, because discovering species on a one-by-one basis is time consuming and expensive. This lack of knowledge is an impediment to conservation aims and other goals important to society. To address this need, the researchers have developed an approach to identifying groups of populations that are likely to consist of several independent species. Because this approach is based on existing ecological and genetic data, the technique will become more refined as additional data are collected. The proposed research will develop and test this approach using data from an ecosystem in the Pacific Northwest that supports much biodiversity, and where several cryptic species have recently been discovered.

The proposed research will develop a predictive framework for the discovery of cryptic biodiversity that can be applied to all members of an ecosystem. In this two-phase framework, researchers will (i) gather environmental, taxonomic, functional, and genetic data from a reference set of taxa native a model ecosystem and identify which of these species contain cryptic diversity, (ii) conduct statistical analyses to identify habitat features shared by the taxa that harbor cryptic diversity, (iii) collect and analyze environmental data for a second set of species to make predictions about which of these species contain cryptic diversity, and (iv) test these predictions via collecting genetic data for the second set of taxa. The temperate rainforests of the Pacific Northwest of North America will serve as the model system. The disjunction of conspecific populations or putative sister-species pairs between Pacific coastal and interior Rocky Mountain segments presents clear hypotheses regarding potential cryptic diversity: either pre-Pleistocene vicariance, which predicts high cryptic diversity, or post- Pleistocene dispersal where which predicts a lack of cryptic diversity. These predictions will be tested by collection of genomic scale data for 24 endemic disjunct plants and animals, and application of Approximate Bayesian Computation to assess support for each hypothesis. This set of taxa will be then used as a training-set for classifying cryptically diverse species from their occurrence data and climatic variables associated with each. Classical multivariate approaches, such as Discriminant Function Analysis, as well as newer decision-tree approaches (such as RandomForest) will be assessed.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
By identifying and describing biological species, systematic biology contribute an essential service to the biological sciences and managers of natural resources. While taxonomy has traditionally operated on a species by species basis, the many threats to biological diversity make it clear that tools for the rapid discovery and characterization of biodiversity are needed. NSF DEB-1457519 supported the development of a predictive framework that repurposed available information, including morphological, climate, genetic, species occurrence, and life history data, in order to identify taxa that were likely to contain multiple biological species under a single species name (i.e., cryptic species). Using  machine learning techniques, we applied the predictive model to data from two representative ecosystems in order to identified taxa from each that may contain cryptic species. The project then proceeded along two paths. First, we evaluated the the accuracy of our predictive framework by collecting additional data from various species included in our model, and found that it generally performed well in the sense that additional data supported the initial prediction from the model. Second, we expanded the predictive framework to evaluate global biodiversity phenomena, including how to identify species that may be at conservation risk, how to identify species traits that are predictive of how a species will respond demographically to climate change, and how to identify factors that lead to population genetic structure within species.


Intellectual MeritThe project demonstrated that certain types of data which are available for most organisms can be used in a machine learning framework to predict which taxa are likely to include undescribed biological species. Predictive models were assembled for the mesic temperate rainforests of the Pacific Northwest of North America and the arid lands of Southwestern North America. After identifying taxa that either were or were not predicted to include cryptic diversity, we conducted exhaustive surveys, collected new samples, and collected new data (including morphological and genetic polymorphism) from snails, slugs, and plants to evaluate the accuracy of the predictions. In addition to these data, the research resulted in the development of several expansions of the predictive framework and new methods for the identification of cryptic species given genetic data. 


Broader ImpactsThe project provided training opportunities and supported professional development for a postdoctoral research scientists, students in Doctoral programs, and multiple undergraduate researchers. Workshops were hosted by project personnel for the dissemination of domain knowledge pertaining to the application of machine learning methods to biodiversity science. Information from various predictive models has been disseminated to conservation management and models have been assembled to identify taxa that may be at conservation risk.


Last Modified: 10/13/2020
Modified by: Bryan C Carstens
